description: Borrowed from Italian vista (“view, sight”), from visto, past participle of vedere (“to see”), from Latin vidēre, present active infinitive of videō (“I see”). Compare vision, video, visa.

entries.meaning: A distant view or prospect, especially one seen through some opening, avenue or passage.
A site offering such a view.
(figuratively) A vision; a view presented to the mind in prospect or in retrospect by the imagination.
examples: a vista of pleasure to come

verbs.description: vista (third-person singular simple present vistas, present participle vistaing, simple past and past participle vistaed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To make a vista or landscape of.
